title: How Varieties of Nationalism Shape Our Polarized Politics
descriptions:
This grant proposal seeks funding for a project titled "How Varieties of Nationalism Shape Our Polarized Politics". The objective of this project is to examine how nationalism influences electoral politics in advanced democracies and to evaluate the potential for national identities to either divide or unite people. The research framework contrasts the traditional transnational cleavage model with a new perspective that focuses on different varieties of nationalism. 

The project will utilize a multi-method comparative research design, with three main work packages. The first package involves analyzing novel survey data to understand how public conceptions of nationalism contribute to partisan divisions. The second package will investigate how elites mobilize support based on different varieties of nationalism. The third package will explore how elite appeals to national identities impact public opinion and partisan hostility.

The expected contributions of this project include advancements in academic research on nationalism and its effects on politics, as well as enriching public debates on societal challenges related to nationalism. This project has the potential to provide valuable insights into the role of nationalism in shaping polarized politics in advanced democracies.

This grant proposal seeks to investigate the impact of nationalism on polarized politics in advanced democracies. Titled "How Varieties of Nationalism Shape Our Polarized Politics," the project aims to understand how different national identities can either divide or unite populations. The research framework contrasts the traditional view of a transnational cultural cleavage with a new perspective that focuses on the diverse manifestations of nationalism.

The proposed theoretical approach involves a multi-method comparative research design. The project comprises three work packages: analyzing survey data to explore how public conceptions of nationalism influence partisan divisions, examining elite mobilization strategies based on different varieties of nationalism, and assessing the effects of elite appeals to national identities on public opinion and partisan hostility.

The expected contributions of this study include advancements in academic research on nationalism and its political implications, as well as enriching public debate on societal challenges related to identity and polarization. By shedding light on the ways in which nationalism shapes political discourse and behavior, this project aims to provide valuable insights for policymakers, scholars, and the general public.
